habitat_description:
The common checkered whiptail occurs in disjointed populations from southeastern Colorado through New Mexico, extreme southeastern Arizona, western Texas, and Chihuahua (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999; Degenhardt et al. 1996, Dixon 2000; Hammerson 1999; Taylor et al. 2003). Jones and Lovich (2009) reported occurrences of this species throughout Trans-Pecos Texas into neighboring areas of Chihuahua and Coahuila, Mexico. In New Mexico, populations are found along the Rio Grande and Pecos River valleys. From New Mexico, this species extends into southeastern Colorado, Oklahoma, and north Texas.

Early reports on the distribution of this species included descriptions of triploid and diploid populations now regarded as different species (Frost and Wright 1988; Wright 1993). Cnemidophorus dixoni (diploid; pattern class F), C. grahamii (diploid; pattern classes C, D, and E), and C. tesselatus (triploid; pattern classes A and B).

The pattern classes A and B are found in Colorado, while pattern classes C, D, and E occur in Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, Oklahoma, and Chihuahua, Mexico (Degenhardt et al. 1996; Dixon 2000; Hammerson 1999). Wright (1993) described the distribution of pattern class F, now known as A. dixoni, to extend from western New Mexico to western Texas. Similarly to their distribution, different populations may occur across different habitats. In Texas, one occurs in flood plains with sandy soils, while the other is predominantly found on gravelly alluvial benches (Parker and Selander 1984). This species is associated with yucca grasslands, mesquite/creosote bush grasslands, Plains grasslands, riparian corridors, and pinon/juniper woodlands as well (Jones and Lovich 2009).

Found in association to pinyon/juniper woodland, mesquite/creosote bush plains, cottonwood/tamarisk in riparian zones, and also in yucca/grass canyon areas. Also, conifer woodlands, shrubland, chaparral, savanna, and also a variety of sparsely vegetated flatlands, canyon slopes, and gullies. Habitats include yucca grassland, and pinon/juniper woodlands.
